prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the question (the author) is in the wrong. The situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together, he pays all the bills because she only works part-time. There was an incident where he forgot his wallet, asked her to pay for takeout under $40, and she had a negative reaction. Now the author is considering making her start paying some bills because of this one incident.

First, the key points: The author has been paying everything, she works part-time, the takeout was a small amount, and her reaction was unpleasant. The author is upset about this and wants her to contribute more now.

I need to evaluate if the author is wrong here. Let's consider both sides. The author might feel that since he pays everything, contributing even a little would be fair. But the incident was small, and using one event to change the entire financial arrangement might be harsh. The girlfriend's job is part-time, so her income is limited. The author is using a single $40 expense to justify making her pay bills, which could put her under financial strain. Also, maybe the author has been paying everything for a reason, perhaps because they had an agreement or she couldn't afford to contribute before. The author's frustration is understandable, but the response might be disproportionate. It's possible that communication about expectations wasn't clear, leading to this situation. The author could be in the wrong if they're making a big change based on a minor incident without considering her financial situation and without discussing it openly. Alternatively, if the author feels that contributing is fair, but the method of enforcing it is abrupt, that could also be an issue. So, the answer might be A (Yes) because the author is overreacting to a small incident and not considering her limited income. Or B (No) if contributing is fair and the author is justified in wanting her to start sharing expenses. But given the context, the key is that the incident was minor, and the author is making a significant change without considering the financial reality. So I think the author is in the wrong.
